post_info.post_title: Lord of the Rings vs. Harry Potter!!!

KM_Scharnhorst

Hmmmm....
 
 Time for...a Pointless Fictional Character Battle(PFCB) Edition #982314-A9C
 
 Aragorn Elessar vs. Harry Potter
 
 Harry: *picks up wand* Now you're going to get it! *starts saying some random spell*
 
 Aragorn: ...*takes Anduril, Flame of the West and stabs Harry* Too slow dude, too slow.
 
 Harry: ...Oh...damn it... *dies*
 
 -----
 
 Legolas, Prince of Mirkwood vs. Ron Weasley
 
 Ron: Heeeey, you're not like the elves where I come from!
 
 Legolas: And where's that?
 
 Ron: England
 
 Legolas: Well duh, those elves suck, and they're not nearly as pretty as me! Anyway.... *shoots Ron with arrow*
 
 Ron: Damn, J.K. Rowling, I'll bloody get your for making me a poor idiot if it's the last thing I-*dies*.
 
 ----
 
 The Witch-King of Angmar vs. Dementor #6
 
 WKoA: You cannot defeat me, all shall fall before the might of Sauron.
 
 Dementor #6:*tries to suck happiness out of The WKoA, but instead goes numb, cold, and lifeless*.
 
 WKoA: Fool, my soul belongs only to Sauron, you are powerless against me.
 
 Dementor #6: Before I die, I have to say, that's a pretty sweet helmet you've got there.
 
 WKoA: It was an office party gift from The Liutenant of the Black Lands.
 
 Dementor #6: *dies*
 
 ----
 
 Last Battle! 
 
 Gandalf the White vs. Dumbledore
 
 Dumbledore: You may have defeated my friends and other assorted characters, but you will not defeat me!
 
 Gandalf: You call yourself a Wizard? You are nothing but a conjurer, a master of smoke and mirrors! You say you are wise? I have lived to see thousands of years of history go by. The fall of kings and tyrants. The rise and fall of great kingdoms, and battles more vast than you can imagine! I am the servant of the Secret Fire, wielder of the Flame of Arnor, your tricks will not save you Dumbledore!
 
 Dumbledore: *Loudly chants various spells and charms, and various shiney runes and symbols appeared and surrounded him like a shell*
 
 Gandalf: Yaaah! *And a great spear of lightning erupted from the white staff of Gandalf, and it smote the magic shell of Dumbledore, throwing him off his feet and launching him backwards approximately 40 feet*.
 
 Dumbledore: *Chants many more spells, long and complicated were they, many which were thought to be lost to all of human kind, save for a few individuals. And Dumbledore raised his hand, and it shone with a white flame. Thus, he struck Gandalf, who had managed to raise Glamdring just in time, to divert some of the force of Dumblefore's attack off it's mark, which still shook the ground with great force.*
 
 Gandalf: So it is, a great battle between two foes.
 
 Dumbledore: Indeed.
 
 Gandalf: nwalca Glamdring, nai yarvaxea rasselya; talhira notto-carrinar...! *And Gandalf's sword roared white, and fired a beam of piercing white directly at Dumbledore, who was blinded. Gandalf raised his staff into the air, and from the sky a mighty arrow of lightning, blazed with immeasurable speed, and it smote Dumbledore, who was left unconscious from the blow. The only thing that saved him from certain death, were his various charms, and incantations.* So it seems, that maybe you are a mightier man than I first thought, but a Wizard you are definitely not.
 
 ----
 
 Lord of the Rings: 4
 Harry Potter: 0

That's evil to make me choose between my children like that :) . I couldn't pick really.
 
 @The Shire- I have to say that I completely disagree with your assessment of the HP books and films. I have read up through the GoF now and I have a hard time ever putting any of them down. Personally, I never found anything boring. I think both the books and the films get better every time. I think the scripts have done a better job of translating from book to film than almost any other I have seen. As far as the acting goes, I don't think Maggie Smith, Alan Rickman, or Richard Harris have ever given a bad performance in their life, and I think the kids do a marvelous job.
The Shire
tno7

LOTR is the standard by which all 'mythical fantasy' tales are judged, at least, here in Ohio. As an author myself, I can only be sceptical when I'm told that my story is better. I hear a lot of talk about LOTR, however, I think 'The Hobbit'  is the story that should be used! It, in my opinion, is better than LOTR!
 As for 'Harry Potter', I can say good things and bad things. The problem with that is: The story is not finished! By speculating, I might add that Neville Longbottom might prove to be Tom Riddle's bane! Ahh, but who knows at this point? I think that every story adds just enough information to make you realize that two things are happening: 1. JK is improving her skills, and, 2. this is a landmark story worthy of all the praise it might get!
 Although, as I have indicated, it is unfair to judge at this point, The Hobbit  remains my favorite story!

post_info.post_title: How Can You Judge An Unfinished Work?

EchoR1

first off, lets do the books:
 
 personally i've read all of the harry potter books already and i honestly enjoyed them very much. i'm still reading lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring after a year of having it. i just can't get into it, i think its because of all the overwhelming detail involved in the books themselves. i love detail, dont get me wrong, but it constantly throws me off beat of the story. there aren't as many details in harry potter as there is in the lord of the rings, but harry potter stays on a certain path that involves detail and plot; lord of the rings puts in way to much detail and hids the plot-after-plot focus.
 
 now onto the movies:
 
 the lord of the rings movies have tons more detail and better visual graphics in both the creatures and places then harry potter. most of the places in lord of the rings were not only built but scaled down digitally and using smaller models to create the epic visual of it. in harry potter, the places were built as an actual set or they used places that were already built so it doesn't have that 'ohhh ahhh' feel to it. not to mention that with lord of the rings, it keeps very well to the books (for the little i've read) but with harry potter, it started out that way but then ended up leaving out so much in movie five and four that it was dissapointing.
 
 characters and cast:
 
 for both movies i think they found the best people to play each roll, i honestly can't put any other person in their places so for this part: i love characters in both.
